issue.body:
When I enter syncthing via http://localhost/#?lang=sv it does not always enter the GUI with the right locale set, but with the default locale configured in app.js.

I think the problem is due to LocaleService.autoConfigLocale(). The current rule says "match available locales of the browser with our availables. If nothing matches use the default locale". We probably have to enhance the rules, so the URL parameter "lang" is dominant over the other two options.

(I am also missing a language setting in the preferences. But this might be another ticket)

body:
I would like to lend a helping hand here. There are just some questions I would like to discuss with you:
1. Where should the language option be added to? The settings modal is already pretty overloaded. Shall we introduce Tabs to the settings modal and place the language selection to one of the new groups?
2. I imagine the language selection as a dropdown button with a scrollable context menu. We currently have about 18 different languages. So the list might be long. Any guides/idas towards a relevant component? This one seems to be pretty good fit for the job: https://github.com/angular-ui/ui-select
3. Where shall we save the selected language? Shall we save it as "per user" setting in the browser or as "per node" setting put it via ajax to an api endpoint? I would prefer the first method.

Just 2 cents.

Regards,
Dennis

1. It's probably about time we roll out tabs, as we've been hiding quite a few settings for quite a while now due to constraints.
2. Looks good, can be used for different things (such as folder path autocomplete?)
3. I guess localStorage is the answer.

1. I don't think the settings modeal is overloaded and I don't mind scrolling to see all available options. If you really must hide less used options use a collapsible div to show advanced settings.
2. Syncthing has already covered most of the main languages worldwide. A simple dropdown is enough unless you want to add "languages" such as Klingon, Pirate, etc. 
3. A simple line in config.xml should suffice

Just make sure that the language names in the GUI are not translated, otherwise there will be 18x18 new translation strings which are not needed. Keep in mind that many users hardly use the GUI at all

The only translated part is the GUI, and changing the language does not change any of the log messages, hence I think local storage makes most sense, as it does not influence anything else apart from the javascript UI.

Regarding 2, I guess it's enough to have a plain dropdown, but there is quite a few languages, so having stuff appear as you type is quite cool, and could be reused by the 'Path to folder' thing, so if we can get people to lay a foundation for some reusable stuff, why not.

Regarding 1, don't care too much, but I was thinking that we eventually could have a `about:config` like thing where we dump all the possible config options, hence tabs would make sense in that case.

I mean not to translate each language name to each language.
e.g. all users see "english, русский, español" 
but not "english, russian, spanish" and the russian user "английский, русский, испанский" and the spanish user "inglés, ruso, español"

a setting in config.xml would allow for company wide rollout or batch file setups

Yeah I understand that.
And I agree with your 'company wide roll out' argument I guess.

Ok, please help me with a little confusion here: Are both of you talking now about a "set operating language via gui"? This would probably be another feature, but I agree on the idea to configure the "Operating Language" over GUI. 

But it would still be nice, if user's can choose their "GUI Language" for themselfs (plus it is not that complicated to do). So that the "operating language" could be different to the viewers/users "gui language". I agree on localStorage here too.

As in my initial post I mean the web GUI language. I suggested "set language via config.xml" because I can't think of a reason why the same device should be accessible with different web GUI languages. Also I don't want to change the GUI language in all different browsers / again after clearing browser cache.

@snnd we are talking about the GUI language, but the GUI language would be stored in the config file, so that it would persist across browsers/cache clears/machines, and would also provide the possibility to be changed by external tools (by modifying the config file).

I guess it's no more than storing an extra string in the GUIConfiguration struct.

There is a great list of language names on [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_language_names) (or [Wikimedia](http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Template:List_of_language_names_ordered_by_code)) that you can use to fill the dropdown

issue.body: I need to set a language of web GUI to english, but there is no such settings available and syncthing is showing me different language.

body:
I would like to urge this issue. It is pretty bad to see language that you dont undertand and not being able to switch to English.

Please consider meanwhile:
1. adding somewhere "use gui in English"..it is completely sufficient, similarly like google has "use google.com in English" at bottom when you access if from different country and it defaults to different language. Maybe if language is not English, then show little UK flag at some corned that would switch to English?
2. advertise somewhere the ability to add language parameter to adrress bar in browser...

It uses your OS/browser locale, hence I am not sure why you are seeing a language you don't understand. Also, I think you can already force a language from the address bar, just I cannot find the part of the code which checks that :dancers: 

Edit:

I think you need to add `?lang=en` query string argument.

Because I am installing syncthing on someone else's computer that has, different locale, which I dont understand very much. I am sure there are plenty other valid reasons to want to see the GUI in english. Forcing some foreign language into GUI, that was not explicitly asked for, without option to switch it, is not good practice.

The query string `?lang=en` doesn't seem to work.
But if you want another language you can always temporarily change the requested language in your browser.
Yeah, true, it's broken. But #1510 should fix it.
